I'm not sure I understand your question.

In both H1.14.x and H3.x, when a seed URI redirects to another URI, the 
default behavior is to mark that new URI as if it were a seed, as well. 
However, this behavior can be turned off. (In H3, this is the 
'seedsRedirectNewSeeds' setting on CandidatesProcessor.)

If it is treated as a new seed, it is announced in a way that scope 
rules that depend on seeds to determine what they accept may update 
themselves, so from that point on a new set of URIs will be accepted. An 
attempt will also be made to append the new seed to the 
seeds-source-text, if it is a writable file on disk.

That seed redirect is treated like other redirects in terms of 
queue-scheduling. In fact, the default 'preferenceEmbedHops' setting 
value in FrontierPreparer, "1", means that single runs of all 
non-navlink ('L') hop-types get a boost in queueing that usually puts 
them in front of other URIs, meaning they will be crawled faster. And, 
if the redirect is to an all-new site, the target URI will be the first 
URI crawled from that queue.

So there shouldn't be any big delay in crawling the redirects. If you 
are seeing a delay � perhaps you might if using a very large seed list, 
because all of the initially-seeded queues would need to have their 
chance to run before the all-new queue becoems 'ready' � there are other 
adjustments you can make to cycle through all the queues more rapidly 
that might help.

- Gordon @ IA

>
>
> HI,Gordon,
> why Heritrix make redirection url as a seed url,and put it into the

> we can make redirection url as a common url,why make it as a seed
> url?only let it can write the redirection record into seeds.txt?
> and why put it into the crawl queue's end?because it will delay so much
> time to crawl.
